messageList.emptyState: Select a feature to see it in action.

getStarted.title: Get Started with Mobvibe
getStarted.description: Two steps to start managing your AI coding agents remotely.
getStarted.step1Description: This installs the CLI and connects your machine to the gateway.

messages.content: What is Mobvibe?

Mobvibe is a **remote AI coding agent management platform**. It lets you monitor and control AI agents (like Claude Code, Codex, Gemini CLI) running on any of your machines — from a single web or native interface.

The architecture is simple:
- **CLI daemon** runs alongside your agent on each machine
- **Gateway** relays messages between CLI and frontends
- **WebUI / Desktop / Mobile** provides the unified interface

Everything is open source, and you can self-host the entire stack.
How is it different from just using the terminal?

Using agents directly in the terminal works, but Mobvibe adds several layers on top:

- **Unified interface** — manage sessions across all machines from one place
- **Session persistence** — reconnect anytime without losing context
- **End-to-end encryption** — your code stays private, even from the gateway
- **Real-time streaming** — see agent output token by token with rich rendering
- **File explorer** — browse remote files, use @mentions to reference them
- **Git integration** — view diffs, blame, branches without leaving the UI
- **Permission approval** — review and approve tool calls before they execute
Which AI agents does Mobvibe support?

Mobvibe supports multiple AI coding agents through the **ACP (Agent Communication Protocol)**:

- **Claude Code** — Anthropic's coding agent
- **Codex** — OpenAI's coding agent
- **Gemini CLI** — Google's coding agent
- **OpenCode** — Open-source coding agent

ACP is a transport-agnostic, streaming-first open protocol. Any agent that speaks ACP can plug into Mobvibe — new agents can be added without modifying the platform.
Can I use different agents at the same time?

Absolutely. Each machine runs its own agent independently, so you can have:

- Claude Code on your main workstation
- Codex on a cloud VM
- Gemini CLI on another server

All sessions appear in the same sidebar, grouped by machine. You can switch between agents instantly and even compare their approaches to the same task.
How do I get started with Mobvibe?

Getting started takes just one command:

```bash
npx @mobvibe/cli login
```

This will:
1. Install the Mobvibe CLI globally
2. Open your browser for authentication
3. Generate an **Ed25519 keypair** for secure signing
4. Register your machine with the gateway

Once logged in, the CLI daemon starts automatically and your machine appears in the web UI at **app.mobvibe.net**.
Do I need to deploy my own gateway?

No — by default, the CLI connects to the **public Mobvibe gateway** at `api.mobvibe.net`. This is the fastest way to get started.

If you want full control, you can self-host:
- The gateway is a Node.js + Express + Socket.io server
- PostgreSQL for persistence
- Deploy anywhere — Docker, Render, or bare metal

Just set `MOBVIBE_GATEWAY_URL` in your CLI config to point to your own instance.
How does Mobvibe protect my code?

Mobvibe supports **end-to-end encryption (E2EE)** using proven cryptographic primitives. When enabled, all messages are encrypted on the CLI daemon before transmission and decrypted only in your browser.

The encryption stack:
- **X25519** for key exchange (Diffie-Hellman over Curve25519)
- **XChaCha20-Poly1305** for authenticated encryption
- **Ed25519** for message signing

The gateway **never sees plaintext** — it only relays encrypted payloads. Even if the gateway is compromised, your code and conversations remain private.
How is the key exchange handled?

During the E2EE handshake, the CLI daemon and web client each generate **ephemeral X25519 keypairs**. After the Diffie-Hellman exchange, a shared secret is derived and used for symmetric encryption.

Key properties:
- **No keys stored on gateway** — it only relays the handshake
- **Forward secrecy** — each session uses fresh keypairs
- **Automatic setup** — E2EE is negotiated transparently when both sides support it

You can verify the encryption status in the session header — a lock icon confirms E2EE is active.
How do I create and manage sessions?

Sessions are the core of Mobvibe — each one represents a conversation with an AI agent. Here's the workflow:

1. **Create** — click "New Session" and select a machine + working directory
2. **Chat** — interact with the agent, send code references with @mentions
3. **Rename** — give sessions meaningful names for easy reference
4. **Archive** — hide completed sessions without deleting them

Sessions persist across reconnections. If your browser disconnects, you pick up right where you left off — full message history, agent context, everything.
Can I resume a session later?

Absolutely. Sessions maintain their full message history including code blocks, tool outputs, and file changes. When you reconnect:

- All previous messages are restored instantly
- The agent retains its context
- File references and @mentions remain valid
- You can continue the conversation seamlessly

This makes Mobvibe ideal for long-running tasks — start a refactoring session in the morning, review progress in the evening, all from any device.
What platforms does Mobvibe support?

Mobvibe is truly cross-platform:

- **Web** — works in any modern browser
- **Desktop** — native apps via Tauri for macOS, Windows, and Linux
- **Mobile** — iOS and Android apps (also via Tauri)

All platforms share the same React codebase and connect to the same gateway, so your sessions sync everywhere.
Are there differences between platforms?

The core experience is identical. Desktop and mobile apps get a few extras:

- **Native notifications** when the agent completes a task
- **Deep linking** to open sessions directly
- **Persistent storage** for offline access to session history
- **System theme** integration that follows your OS appearance

The web version works great too — it's the easiest way to get started.
How does Mobvibe handle multiple machines?

Mobvibe connects to **AI coding agents** running on any of your machines through a central gateway. Each machine runs a lightweight CLI daemon that registers with the gateway, making all your development environments accessible from a single interface.

You can switch between machines instantly, run commands remotely, and manage sessions across your entire fleet — whether it's a local workstation, a cloud VM, or a headless server.
Can I see all my machines at once?

Yes! The sidebar groups sessions by **backend** (machine). Each backend shows its connection status and active sessions. You can expand or collapse groups, and quickly jump between any session on any machine.
How does real-time streaming work?

Mobvibe streams AI responses **token by token** in real time via WebSocket. As the agent thinks and writes code, you see every character appear instantly — no waiting for the full response.

This includes:
- **Markdown rendering** as it streams
- **Syntax-highlighted code blocks** that build up live
- **Tool call results** that expand inline
- **Thinking indicators** while the agent reasons
What about terminal output?

Terminal output from commands the agent runs is also streamed in real time. You'll see `stdout` and `stderr` appear as the command executes, with ANSI colors rendered naturally. It feels like watching a terminal session unfold.
Tell me about the file explorer.

The built-in **file explorer** lets you browse the remote file system of any connected machine directly from the web UI. You can:

- Navigate directories with a familiar tree view
- **Preview files** with syntax highlighting
- Reference files in your messages using `@filename` mentions
- See which files the agent has modified during a session
- Use the **command palette** (`Ctrl+K`) to quickly jump to any file
How does the file search work?

Mobvibe uses **uFuzzy** for blazing-fast fuzzy file search. Type `@` in the message input to trigger the file picker, then start typing — it matches filenames, paths, and even partial fragments.

The command palette (`Ctrl+K`) provides the same search across all files in the working directory. Results are ranked by relevance, and you can navigate with keyboard shortcuts.

Selected files get attached as context — the agent sees their contents along with your message. Perfect for requests like "refactor `@utils.ts` to use async/await".
What Git features does Mobvibe offer?

Mobvibe includes a comprehensive **Git integration** with 13 built-in functions accessible from the web UI:

- **Diff viewer** — side-by-side or unified diff for any file or commit
- **Blame** — see who changed each line and when
- **Branch management** — create, switch, and delete branches
- **Commit history** — browse the full log with filtering
- **Status** — see staged, unstaged, and untracked changes
- **Stash** — save and restore work in progress

All operations run on the remote machine and results stream back in real time.
Are Git operations executed remotely?

Yes — all Git operations execute on the remote machine through the CLI daemon's **RPC pipeline**. Results are streamed back to your browser in real time.

When E2EE is enabled, file contents in diffs and blame output are encrypted end-to-end — the gateway never sees your source code.

This means you can review diffs, browse commit history, and manage branches on a remote server, all from your phone or tablet — no SSH required.
